claim: If you travel to France and Denmark, you'll need to change dollars into euros and krone.

supporting.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so travelers will need to exchange dollars for euros.

attacks.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so travelers will need to exchange dollars for euros.
Many credit cards offer no foreign transaction fees and automatically convert currency at competitive rates, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.
Some travelers may already have euros from previous trips or other sources, eliminating the immediate need to exchange dollars.
Credit card acceptance is not universal in France, especially in rural areas or small businesses, making physical euros necessary.
Exchange rates offered by credit cards may still be less favorable than certain local exchange services, making direct exchange preferable in some cases.
Travelers with euros from previous trips may not have enough for their current needs, still requiring additional exchange.

supporting.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, not the euro, so travelers will need to exchange dollars for krone.

attacks.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, not the euro, so travelers will need to exchange dollars for krone.
Many businesses in Denmark accept euros despite the official currency being the krone, reducing the need for immediate exchange.
Some travelers may use credit cards that automatically handle currency conversion, avoiding the need for physical exchange.
Even if euros are accepted, the exchange rates offered by businesses are often unfavorable compared to official exchange services.
Credit card transactions may incur foreign transaction fees, making direct currency exchange more cost-effective for some travelers.

supporting.text: Some businesses in Denmark, especially in tourist areas, may accept euros, reducing the immediate need to exchange dollars for krone.

attacks.text: Some businesses in Denmark, especially in tourist areas, may accept euros, reducing the immediate need to exchange dollars for krone.
Many businesses in Denmark still prefer krone, and relying on euros may limit your options or result in unfavorable exchange rates.
Even if euros are accepted, you may still need krone for public transportation, local markets, or non-tourist areas.
Tourist areas often have higher prices when accepting euros, making it more economical to use krone.
Public transportation systems in Denmark typically require payment in krone, making it essential to exchange currency.

supporting.text: Travelers using international credit or debit cards may avoid currency exchange altogether by paying directly in local currencies with favorable exchange rates.

attacks.text: Travelers using international credit or debit cards may avoid currency exchange altogether by paying directly in local currencies with favorable exchange rates.
Many small businesses and vendors in France and Denmark only accept cash, making currency exchange necessary.
International credit cards often charge high foreign transaction fees, making direct payments less favorable than exchanging currency.
Tourist-heavy areas in France and Denmark are increasingly cashless, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.
Some credit cards offer zero foreign transaction fees, making direct payments more cost-effective than exchanging currency.
